iv PREFACE.

Those on the Epistle to Philemon cannot easily be as- signed to any particular date. The promise he mentions in the last Homily, p. 360. does not seem to afford a clue to it, but may possibly do so. The composition of these Ho- milies has been remarked on as negligent by Hemsterhusius‚ so that he takes them to have been extemporaneous effia- sions taken down by others. There may be some ground for this in the style, and in the paraphrastic character of the various readings, but as a commentary they are unusually close and exact, and point out much of what regards the persuasive character of the Epistle that is not generally noticed.

For the Translation and some illustrative notes, the Editors are indebted to the Rev. J AMES TWEED, M.A. of Corpus Christi College, Cambridge. The text of the New Paris edition has been chiefly used, as it is improved from the Benedictine. Savile's has been compared with it in many parts, and in every difficulty, and where both failed, a better reading has been sometimes found in the MS. marked Β, which is in the British Museum marked Burney 48. The differences are however slight, and affect the Greek more than the Translation. A Venice MS. which usually agrees with this, has been collated for the Homilies on the Epistle to Philemon. An old Latin version published at Basle has been noticed in some placeS, where its 'variations appear to be derived from Greek copies.
